page.title: 01LANDSCAPE NORTH OSWESTRY
page.content: The area forms an undulationg slope between the Welsh Hills and the Shropshire Plain. The height drops from 2OOm in west to 1OOm in east.It is wooded with deciduous trees and the hedgerows have a wide variety of trees. Several large buildings dominatee their rural surroundings, Orthopaedic Hospital, Derwen College, Whittington House. The central area is reclaimed land from the army where sports facilities, farming and a special gypsy site are the main uses. The south west corner is an area of houses built when the railway came to Oswestry. It has had environmental improvements. Dairy farming is the chief occupation so grass, barley, and fodder crops occupy most of the fields.
